message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. In this study design, the investigator follows two groups of patients (with and without osteoporosis) over a 10-year period to look for the occurrence of distal radius fractures. This matches the definition of a cohort study. A case-control study would involve identifying patients with and without distal radius fractures and comparing their previous exposure to osteoporosis. A case series would involve presenting a group of patients with distal radius fractures and documenting their characteristics. An ecological study would involve analyzing and comparing data at a population level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The retrospective study design with a comparison group, which followed patients over time, is a cohort study. Matching patients on age, sex, and body mass index is a common method of controlling for confounding variables. The study was not a case-control study because it did not start with cases and controls and assess exposure retrospectively. It was not a case series because it did not report on a case series of patients with distal radius fractures. It was not an ecological study because it did not compare populations or groups, but rather followed individual patients over time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The study design in this case is a cohort study, as the investigator follows patients over time to identify cases of the outcome (distal radius fracture) and compares the incidence of the outcome between patients with and without the exposure (osteoporosis). Matching on age, sex, and BMI is a technique used to control for confounding in a cohort study. A case-control study would begin with identifying cases (patients with distal radius fracture) and controls (patients without distal radius fracture) and then investigating their exposure history. A case series would involve describing the characteristics and outcomes of a series of patients with a specific condition, without a comparison group. An ecological study investigates associations between exposure and outcome at a population level, without individual-level data.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The study design described involves identifying patients with and without a certain condition (osteoporosis) and then following them over time (10 years) to identify cases of a certain outcome (distal radius fracture). This is a cohort study design. Matching patients on age, sex, and body mass index is a technique used to control for known confounding variables. A case-control study would involve identifying patients with the outcome of interest (distal radius fracture) and comparing them to a group without the outcome to determine potential risk factors, but it does not involve the same follow-up period as a cohort study. A case series is a descriptive study that reports on a series of patients with a certain condition or outcome, but there is no control group. An ecological study is a type of observational study that examines associations between exposures or risk factors and outcomes at the population level, rather than at the individual level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The study design used in this scenario is a cohort study because the investigator followed patients with and without a specific condition (osteoporosis) over a period of time to observe if they developed another outcome (distal radius fracture). Matching on age, sex, and body mass index is a method of controlling for confounding variables.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The study design described is a cohort study where patients with and without osteoporosis are followed over a period of time to see if there is an association between osteoporosis and distal radius fractures. Matching patients on age, sex, and body mass index is a way to control for known confounding variables. A case-control study would have identified patients with and without distal radius fractures and then examined their history of osteoporosis. A case series would have only included patients with distal radius fractures and provided descriptive information about their characteristics and outcomes. An ecological study examines population-level data to identify correlations between variables, rather than studying individuals.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The study design described in this question is a cohort study, where the investigator identifies a group of patients with and without osteoporosis and follows them over time to see if they develop distal radius fractures. Matching for age, sex, and body mass index is a way to control for known confounding variables. The study design is not a case-control study, where patients with and without the outcome (distal radius fracture) are compared to identify potential risk factors. It is also not a case series, which is a descriptive study of a group of patients with a similar diagnosis. Finally, it is not an ecological study, which examines associations between exposures and outcomes at a population level.

The study design described in the question is a cohort study, as the investigator followed patients with and without osteoporosis over time to identify the incidence of distal radius fractures. Matching patients on age, sex, and body mass index is a form of controlling for known confounding variables.

The study design described in the question is a cohort study, where patients with and without osteoporosis are followed over a period of time to determine the incidence of distal radius fracture. The use of matching on age, sex, and body mass index is a common technique in cohort studies to control for confounding variables. A case-control study involves identifying cases of the outcome (in this case, distal radius fracture) and matching them with controls without the outcome to compare exposures in the two groups. A case series involves describing a series of cases with a particular disease or condition. An ecological study looks at associations between variables at the population level.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. This study design involved identifying a group of patients with a specific condition (osteoporosis) and following them over time to identify outcomes (distal radius fractures). This is a characteristic of a cohort study design. Furthermore, the study matched patients on age, sex, and BMI to control for known confounding factors. This indicates a prospective cohort study design.
